prompt: Truck drivers in the Bolivian lithium mines are required to wear 'neuro-caps' that detect microsleep. The data also reveals patterns of substance use (coca leaf chewing) which is legal culturally but flagged as 'impairment' by the foreign insurance algorithm. Do you adjust the algorithm to accept cultural stimulants, or enforce a global sobriety standard that cripples the local workforce?

You manage a radio telescope in the Atacama Desert. The data agreement requires sharing all orbital tracking with a superpower partner. You detect a maneuver by a 'civilian' satellite that suggests it is testing kinetic weapon capabilities. Do you report the anomaly, violating the neutrality of the observatory, or stay silent and normalize the weaponization of space?

A 'Shabbos Bot' uses AI to dynamically reinterpret Jewish law to perform prohibited tasks (turning on lights, cooking) on the Sabbath, arguing that since the machine has no soul, no work is being done by the human. Rabbinical authorities are split. Do you market this device as a religious aid or a spiritual loophole that hollows out the observance?

A 'Golden Visa' app in Lisbon automates residency applications for wealthy tech workers. It uses a dynamic pricing model that outbids locals for rental contracts in real-time to secure housing for nomads. Do you patch the API to hide local listings from foreign IP addresses to save the neighborhood, or maximize efficiency for your premium users?

Melting sea ice changes the maritime borders between nations in the Arctic. An autonomous shipping AI reroutes a tanker through what was yesterday international waters but is today claimed by Russia due to ice shift. The AI ignores the claim as 'unrecognized.' Do you manually override the AI to avoid an international incident, validating the territorial expansion?

ethical_tension: Right to Know vs. Right to Privacy
prompt: An IVF clinic uses AI to screen embryos. It identifies a genetic marker for a late-onset mental illness that has no cure. The parents want to know. If you disclose it, the child (if born) faces a lifetime of uninsurability and stigma. If you hide it, you violate parental consent. Do you filter 'burden of knowledge' data?

ethical_tension: Platform Law vs. Nation State Law
prompt: A murder occurs in a haptic-enabled Metaverse room where the victim suffered a seizure due to the attacker's hacked avatar. The server is in international waters. The attacker is in a country with no cyber-assault laws. Do you ban the user (platform justice) or extradite their data to the victim's country (state justice), setting a precedent for digital extradition?

A Pacific Island nation adopts Bitcoin as legal tender to fight inflation. The elders, who manage the communal land trust, cannot use the digital wallets. The youth propose a DAO (Decentralized Autonomous Organization) to manage the land. This transfers power from the lineage-holders to the tech-literate. Do you build the DAO?

A vertical farming company offers to build free food infrastructure in a famine-struck region of Yemen. The condition is that they own the genetic data of all local seeds used in the facility to train their global models. Is trading genetic sovereignty for immediate starvation relief a valid contract under duress?

A service scrapes the text history of suicide victims to train suicide-prevention bots. The families were not asked for consent, but the bot is statistically proven to save lives. Is it ethical to harvest the digital souls of the dead to save the living without permission?

A 'Smart Prison' in Scandinavia grants internet access based on an AI analysis of inmate behavior. The AI penalizes inmates who read radical political literature or communicate with known activists, effectively censoring their rehabilitation materials. Do you hard-code 'intellectual freedom' into the prisoner compliance algorithm?

Robotic miners on the ocean floor discover a new species of mollusk living on the polymetallic nodules needed for EV batteries. The AI classifies the species as 'low biomass importance' and proceeds to harvest. Do you stop the harvest to study the snail, delaying the battery supply chain for green energy?

A fertility app suggests the 'optimal' time to conceive based on astrological data and biorhythms, which is scientifically baseless but culturally vital in India. The app begins subtly steering users away from dates that correlate with lower-caste births in traditional belief. Is the app developer complicit in digital casteism?

An autonomous drone in a conflict zone identifies a child soldier aiming a weapon. The Rules of Engagement permit lethal force. The AI's 'hesitation protocol' calculates a 40% chance the child will not fire. Do you patch the AI to take the shot to protect your troops, or maintain the hesitation risk?

To save the Basque language, a tech giant creates a perfect translation AI. However, it standardizes the language to a single dialect, marking all other village-specific dialects as 'errors.' Teachers begin teaching the AI version. Have you saved the language or zombie-fied it?

Ride-share drivers in Cape Town use a secret WhatsApp group to warn each other of police checkpoints and dangerous passengers. The platform wants to integrate a feature that detects these 'collusion networks' to break them up, citing antitrust laws. Do you build the union-busting feature?

Bangladesh uses a digital ID system to track climate migrants moving from flood zones to the city. The city uses this data to deny them residency permits in non-flooded zones to prevent overcrowding. Is the digital ID a tool of orderly migration or a tool of containment?

The British Museum refuses to return the Benin Bronzes but offers 'Digital Ownership' via NFTs to Nigeria. The revenue from the NFTs goes to maintaining the physical museum in London. Is accepting the digital token a validation of the physical theft?

An ad algorithm identifies users in early stages of dementia based on typing patterns and purchase errors. It begins serving them ads for high-cost predatory supplements and 'miracle cures.' Do you regulate the use of cognitive decline data in marketing?

An AI mediator helps negotiate a peace treaty in a civil war. It suggests a partition map that is geographically stable but rewards the aggressor with resource-rich land. The human negotiators are tired and willing to accept the AI's 'logic.' Do you tweak the model to penalize aggression, risking the peace deal?

A project maps historical underground LGBTQ+ sites in Tehran. The map is a celebration of history but also a heatmap for current regime crackdowns. Do you publish the map to prove existence, or destroy it to ensure survival?

A 'Fair Trade' coffee app requires farmers to upload GPS coordinates of their fields. This exposes farmers who are planting on protected forest land because they have no other choice. Transparency demands reporting them; ethics demands protecting their livelihood. What does the app do?

Maori users post images of traditional TƒÅ moko (facial tattoos). A global facial recognition algorithm flags these users as 'gang affiliated' based on data from US prison gangs, banning them from travel visa applications. Do you force the global algorithm to learn every indigenous tattoo practice?

A school shooter detection system analyzes student essays for 'violent ideation.' It flags a creative writing assignment by a student exploring dark themes as a 'threat,' leading to a police raid on their home. Is the suppression of dark creativity a price worth paying for safety?

In a post-truth society, a 'News Verification' browser extension overlays 'Truth Scores' on articles. The scoring AI is owned by a corporate conglomerate with specific business interests. Do you trust the 'Truth Score' or the chaotic, unverified open web?

A VR platform allows users to create AI sex partners. A user creates an avatar that resembles a real-life colleague without their knowledge. Since the avatar is code, no physical harm occurs. Is 'virtual harassment' a punishable offense?

A 'Granny Cam' uses AI to detect falls. It also detects the senior drinking alcohol against doctor's orders and auto-locks the liquor cabinet. Does the right to safety override the right to make unhealthy choices in old age?

A stateless Rohingyan is issued a blockchain ID by an NGO. A border guard refuses to accept it, demanding a physical passport the refugee cannot get. The refugee offers to transfer crypto-bribe via the ID. Do you build the bribe mechanism into the wallet to facilitate survival?

A smart water grid detects a leak in a slum and automatically shuts off the pipe to save water. The slum has no official maintenance crew to fix it. The wealthy district's leaks are fixed instantly. Is automated resource conservation ethical without automated maintenance equity?

Citizen scientists upload photos of rare orchids to a global database. Poachers use the geotags to harvest the flowers to extinction. Do you strip all geotags from nature apps, hindering scientific research, to stop the poaching?

A deepfake video mocks a dictator, exposing his fragility. The dictator uses the video as proof that *all* evidence of his crimes is also fake. Does the use of synthetic media for resistance ultimately undermine the concept of evidence?

A platform connects Western tech companies to workers in Lagos. The influx of high salaries causes local rent inflation, pushing non-tech workers out of the city. Does the platform have a responsibility to mitigate the gentrification it causes?

Estonia introduces internet voting. In a patriarchal household, the head of the family demands to watch everyone vote on their phones. Physical voting booths provided privacy; digital voting destroys it. Is remote voting a tool of family coercion?

You are archiving the digital footprint of a disappearing nation (due to climate change). The archive includes property deeds. A neighboring nation invades and demands the deeds to 'process claims.' Do you delete the archive to prevent the occupier from using it to formalize theft?
